title: Understanding Gynaecological Ultrasound
subtitle: What it is, why it's done, and what to expect

content.value: A gynaecological (pelvic) ultrasound is a safe and painless way to examine the uterus, ovaries, fallopian tubes and other pelvic organs. It uses **sound waves** to create real-time images with no radiation involved.

content.description: Quick, safe procedure with no radiation

content.title: What We Can See
content.description: Uterus size and shape, Ovaries and follicles, Endometrial lining thickness, Any abnormalities or cysts

items.title: What It Can Help With
items.content: Check for abnormalities, Investigate pelvic pain, Assess fertility issues, Monitor early pregnancy, Measure endometrium

content.title: Further Investigation
content.description: If the womb lining is thicker than expected, you may be offered a hysteroscopy to investigate further.

items.title: Transabdominal Ultrasound
items.description: Probe on lower tummy, gives broad view, may require full bladder

items.title: Transvaginal Ultrasound
items.description: Probe gently inserted, gives closer detailed images, often used for fertility assessment

content.title: Safety
content.description: Both types are safe and usually painless with no known risks.

steps: Positioning - lie on examination couch comfortably
Gel Application - warm gel on lower abdomen
Scanning - probe moved gently across skin
Transvaginal if needed - probe covered with sheath and lubricated

content.title: Comfort
content.description: Most patients find the procedure comfortable and painless.

items.title: What if something is found
items.content: Your doctor will discuss treatment options or follow-up procedures

content.title: No Known Risks
content.description: There are no known risks from diagnostic ultrasound at medical levels.

content.value: It's completely normal to feel nervous about an intimate scan.

content.title: Reassurance
content.description: This is a routine and safe procedure designed to give you clarity and reassurance.
